comments:
When performing an "Open Declaration" in a source file, I've found the process
generates an NPE on two separate occasions:

1.  When opening a classes without a constructor.
2.  When opening a supertype method called via a subtype object.

Which build?
I can't reproduce this problem. Do you have special steps to reproduce?

Moving to Platform/UI, since the NPE is in WorkbenchPartReference.

Build id:  I20050627-1435

When I open up my class file, I highlight a method whose declaration I wish to
open.  I press "F3" to open the declaration, and then I receive a dialog box
saying the "Open Declaration" didn't complete properly do to a
NullPointerException.  The method is a "static" method and the class in which is
resides does not have a constructor.

As far as a the second issue goes, I have not been able to reproduce it after I
opened the ticket.  The first one I can reproduce quite easily.

Is this still an issue? ... I was unable to reproduce it in the java perspective
on windows XP:
Version: 3.1.0
Build id: I20050627-1435


I used a class with no constructor and a member function that calls into a
static method on another class (also with no constructor).  Hit F3 a couple of
times, open and closed some editors, hopped from one class to the other.

How many projects were in your workspace?  Were there any of the org.eclipse
projects downloaded from HEAD, or imported from external plugins and fragments?

The stack trace looks like it's a recursive creation attempt, they do happen
occasionally.

PW

This is still an issue for me.  It could be my setup.  I'll reinstall to see if
it helps.  I should've done this earlier, but I've been under the gun so I
haven't taken the time.

Bradley, any luck with reproducing this on a new install?

PW

This is an issue now.  However, there are no identifying situations in which
this occurs.  One thing I've noticed is the memory usage is close to 300Mb+. 
I'm executing Eclipse with the arguments "-clean -vmargs -Xms256M -Xmx256M". 
I've upgraded to Eclipse 3.1.1 and the problem still exists.

My installation was fine for a while.  Then the problem resurfaced last week. 
I'm at a loss right now.  It's really more of an annoyance than anything.

I was also using IBM JDK 1.4.1.  I believe I may have been using this JDK the
last time, but I can't be certain.
